comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content:
Library and Archives Canada has 3 to choose from:
1. BLAY, ALBERT JESSE 05/05/1883   1054259 RG 150, Accession 1992-93/166, Box 816 - 50
2. BLAY, ARTHUR 20/03/1880   862338 RG 150, Accession 1992-93/166, Box 816 - 52
3. BLAY, ARTHUR 30/08/1896   823013 RG 150, Accession 1992-93/166, Box 816 - 51

Ancestry.ca has:
Canada, Soldiers of the First World War, 1914-1918
Regimental number 1054259
244th Battalion
Name: Albert Blay
Birth: Newport, Vermont, United States of America
Residence: Montreal Quebec

Canada, Soldiers of the First World War, 1914-1918
Regimental number 862338
180th Battalion
Name: Arthur Blay
Birth: Middlesex, England
Residence: Toronto, Canada

Canada, Soldiers of the First World War, 1914-1918
Regimental number 823013
142nd Battalion
Name: Arthur Blay
Birth: Stratford, Ontario
Residence: London, Ontario

Might this last soldier - Arthur Blay - be our man based on his apparent age in the photograph?

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Arthur Bradshaw Blay's 30 Nov 1915 Attestation Papers can be found here trees.ancestry.com/view/Military.aspx?tid=11726353&pi... He was born 30 Aug 1896 in Stratford, Ontario and his father is Adam Blay. His trade or calling is given as Clerk. His last address is 805 Dundas St, London, Ont. Regiment Number: 823013 142nd Battalion. His "Allegiance" was to the United States of America. Was he to marry in 1926 in London, Ontario to Wilda Howe? With issue? See wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=:2...

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: RootsWeb Message Boards has postings which state that Adam Blay emigrated from Lincoln, England to Ontario in 1890 ? and was married to Elizabeth Ann Mott in 1894.They had six children:George 1894, Arthur 1896, John 1899, James 1905, Reginald 1907 and Gordon 1911. The 1901 and 1911 Canadian Censuses give information about the family: automatedgenealogy.com/uidlinks/Links.jsp?uid=150667763 (Stratford was a subdistrict of Perth)

comment.author: 101632927@N05
comment._content: I feel sure that this is a relative of mine,I am a Blay and there was a large part of the Blay family that moved to Canada at the end of the 19th century & beginning of the 20th century.I will look into it as my brother & myself have been tracing our family tree recently.
